questions.text: All are the risk factors for gallstone formation except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Rapid weight gain is not a known risk factor for the formation of gallstones.
  • Instead, rapid weight loss is a recognised trigger for cholesterol gallstone formation due to biliary stasis and increased cholesterol secretion.

Gallstones are of two main types:

  • Cholesterol stones (most common in the West)
  • Pigment stones (more common in Asians)

Known risk factors include:

Cholesterol Stones:

  • Demographic: Northern and Latin Americans, Native Americans, Mexican Americans
  • Female sex hormones: Oral contraceptives, pregnancy (Option A), female gender
  • Metabolic: Obesity, rapid weight loss, insulin resistance, dyslipidemia (Option B)
  • Others: Gallbladder stasis, inborn bile acid metabolism disorders

Pigment Stones:

  • Demographic: Asian, rural population
  • Hemolysis (Option D): e.g., sickle cell disease, hereditary spherocytosis
  • Biliary infections
  • GI disorders: Ileal disease or resection, cystic fibrosis with pancreatic insufficiency

questions.text: Empyema of the gallbladder and gangrenous cholecystitis are seen in:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Acute calculous cholecystitis is caused by obstruction of the cystic duct or gallbladder neck by a stone.
  • The lumen fills with cloudy bile containing fibrin, pus, and haemorrhage.
  • When the exudate is mostly pus, it's called gallbladder empyema.
  • If inflammation is severe, the wall becomes green-black and necrotic, termed gangrenous cholecystitis.
  • The presence of stones is the key feature distinguishing this from the acalculous type.

Explanation of other options:

Acute Acalculous Cholecystitis (Option B): Morphologically very similar to the calculous type, but stones are absent. Though severe forms can cause gangrene, empyema (pure pus) is not commonly described.

Chronic Cholecystitis (Option C): Results from repeated episodes of mild inflammation. Features fibrosis and wall thickening, but not empyema or gangrene.

None of the above (Option D): Incorrect because both empyema and gangrenous changes are hallmarks of acute calculous cholecystitis.

questions.text: What is the most common type of gallstone found in chronic cholecystitis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The most common type of gallstone in chronic cholecystitis is the cholesterol stone.
  • Chronic inflammation of the gallbladder alters bile composition and reduces motility, leading to cholesterol supersaturation and precipitation.
  • Over time, cholesterol accumulates and solidifies to form pure or mixed cholesterol stones.

Explanation of other options:

Pigmented stones (Option B): These are less commonly associated with chronic cholecystitis and more often seen in conditions like chronic hemolysis or biliary infections, not the typical presentation in chronic cholecystitis.

Mixed stones (Option C): Although these can occur in chronic cholecystitis, they are less specific. Cholesterol remains the predominant component, making cholesterol stones more characteristic.

Key takeaways:

questions.text: A 41-year-old obese female presents to an acute care clinic with complaints of pain on the right side of her abdomen that started suddenly a few hours ago and has been increasing in severity. She also reports that she is nauseated and has vomited three times. She does not smoke, uses alcohol only occasionally, and does not use IV drugs. She has been married for 20 years and has five children. Her only past medical history is a fractured right radius during childhood. She has had no surgeries. Her vital signs are a temperature of 99.3°F, pulse of 109 bpm, and blood pressure of 131/81 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals slight scleral icterus. Of the following, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The clinical features: female sex, age >40, obesity, multiparity (5 children), are classic risk factors for cholesterol gallstones.
  • The patient's sudden right upper quadrant pain, nausea, vomiting, tachycardia, and mild fever support the diagnosis of acute cholecystitis, most commonly caused by gallstones (calculous) obstructing the cystic duct.

Explanation of Other Options:

Acute hepatitis (Option A): May cause jaundice and malaise, but typically presents with diffuse abdominal discomfort, not acute RUQ pain with vomiting and fever.

Acute appendicitis (Option B): Classically presents with periumbilical pain shifting to the right lower quadrant, not the right upper quadrant.

Intestinal obstruction (Option C): Usually presents with diffuse abdominal pain, distention, and obstipation, not localised RUQ pain or scleral icterus.

questions.text: What is the most common gene mutation found in pancreatic solid pseudopapillary neoplasm?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • CTNNB1, the gene encoding β-catenin, is mutated in >90% of SPNs, leading to nuclear and cytoplasmic accumulation of β-catenin, a key diagnostic clue.
  • Solid pseudopapillary neoplasms (SPNs) are rare pancreatic tumours most commonly affecting young women.
  • Histologically, they show solid and pseudopapillary architecture with hemorrhagic cystic degeneration.
  • This mutation is highly specific for SPNs and not found in other pancreatic neoplasms like IPMNs or mucinous cystic neoplasms.

Explanation of other options:

KIT (Option B): Mutations in KIT are seen in gastrointestinal stromal tumours (GISTs), not SPNs. It is not a driver gene in pancreatic tumours.

PDGFRA (Option C): Like KIT, PDGFRA mutations are also common in GISTs and are not involved in SPNs.

RAS (typically referring to KRAS) (Option D): KRAS mutations are common in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma and IPMNs, but are absent in SPNs.

questions.text: Which is the normal site for activation of pancreatic digestive proenzymes?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Most pancreatic digestive enzymes (like trypsin, chymotrypsin, and elastase) are produced as inactive zymogens (proenzymes) to prevent autodigestion of the pancreas.
  • These zymogens are stored in zymogen granules inside acinar cells of the pancreas.
  • Trypsinogen is the key zymogen and is normally activated in the small intestine (duodenum) by the enzyme enteropeptidase (also called enterokinase), which converts trypsinogen → trypsin.
  • Trypsin then activates other proenzymes.

Explanation of other options:

Pancreatic parenchyma (Option A): Activation of enzymes here is abnormal and pathological, as seen in acute pancreatitis.

Pancreatic duct (Option B): Zymogens are secreted into the ducts but not activated here under normal conditions.

Stomach (Option D): The Stomach secretes pepsinogen (from chief cells), not pancreatic enzymes.

questions.text: Which part of the biliary tree is involved in the congenital cystic dilatation known as a choledochocele?
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

  • Choledochocele (Todani Type III) is a congenital cystic dilatation specifically involving the distal intramural portion of the common bile duct, within the wall of the duodenum.
  • It causes a ballooning or protrusion into the duodenal lumen.
  • This differentiates it from other types that affect the extrahepatic or intrahepatic bile ducts.

Todani Classification of Choledochal Cysts:

Explanation of other options:

Common hepatic duct (Option A): is typically involved in Type II or IV cysts.

Cystic duct (Option C): not involved in choledochal cysts.

Intrahepatic biliary tree (Option D): involved in Type V (Caroli disease), not Type III.

questions.text: In pancreatic carcinoma, which of the following organs are the most common sites for distant metastasis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Common sites of distant metastasis in pancreatic carcinoma:
    • Liver (most frequent)
    • Lung
    • Bone
    • Peritoneum
  • Pancreatic carcinoma often metastasises early due to its anatomical proximity to major vessels and lymphatic routes.

Common Sites of Metastasis in Abdominal Organ Cancers:

Explanation of other options:

Spleen/Adrenal (Option A): Rare metastatic sites, not typical for pancreatic carcinoma.

Transverse colon/Stomach (Option B): Direct invasion can occur, but these are not considered distant metastatic sites.

Brain/Liver (Option D): While the liver is common, brain metastasis is very rare in pancreatic carcinoma.

questions.text:
Which of the following hormone/s is/are secreted by the islet cells of the pancreas?
1. Somatostatin
2. Glucagon
3. Insulin
4. Thyroxine
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The islets of Langerhans are clusters of endocrine cells within the pancreas responsible for hormone secretion. These cells include:
    • Alpha (α) cells → secrete Glucagon
    • Beta (β) cells → secrete Insulin
    • Delta (δ) cells → secrete Somatostatin
  • These hormones regulate blood glucose levels and other aspects of metabolism.
  • Somatomedin C (also known as IGF-1) is not secreted by pancreatic islets. It is primarily produced in the liver in response to growth hormone.

questions.text:
Which of the following is/are the morphological feature(s) of acute pancreatitis?
1. Microvascular injury and oedema
2. Fat necrosis and acute inflammation
3. Destruction of the pancreatic parenchyma and blood vessels
4. Infiltration by eosinophils
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Acute pancreatitis is a medical emergency marked by inappropriate activation of pancreatic enzymes that leads to autodigestion of the pancreas.

Key Morphological Features:

  1. Microvascular leakage → oedema (due to inflammation and vascular injury)
  2. Fat necrosis - due to activated lipase
  3. Acute inflammation - infiltration by neutrophils
  4. Proteolytic destruction of acinar tissue → parenchymal necrosis
  5. Blood vessel damage → haemorrhage

Hence, options 1, 2, and 3 are correct.

  • Infiltration by eosinophils: Not a feature of acute pancreatitis.
  • Neutrophils
  • Eosinophils are typically seen in parasitic infections, drug reactions, or autoimmune disorders.

Morphology of Acute Pancreatitis

Gross:

  • Swollen, edematous pancreas
  • Foci of yellow-white fat necrosis
  • Areas of haemorrhage in severe cases

Microscopy:

  • Edema
  • Acinar cell necrosis
  • Fat necrosis (with calcium soap formation)
  • Neutrophilic infiltration
  • Vascular destruction → haemorrhage

questions.text:
A case of an alcoholic person presented to the trauma care centre with severe incapacitating abdominal pain referred to the upper back. Laboratory investigation showed raised serum amylase and lipase. Which of the following correctly describes the patient's condition clinically?
1. It is a medical emergency
2. The surgeon will be able to see the chalky deposits in the omentum
3. The patient is having an acute pancreatitis
4. Raised serum prolactin will always accompany the above condition.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient is presenting with acute pancreatitis, most likely due to alcoholism, a common risk factor. This diagnosis is supported by the classic triad of:
    • Sudden onset of severe epigastric pain radiating to the back
    • Elevated serum amylase and lipase
    • History of alcohol abuse
  1. It is a medical emergency - True
    • Acute pancreatitis, especially with severe incapacitating abdominal pain and raised amylase/lipase, constitutes a medical emergency.
    • Prompt supportive care is essential to prevent complications like shock, necrosis, or multi-organ failure.
  2. Surgeon will be able to see the chalky deposits in omentum - True
    • In acute necrotising pancreatitis, released lipases act on peripancreatic fat, leading to fat necrosis.
    • This causes chalky white calcium soap deposits in mesentery, omentum, and peritoneum-visible during surgery/autopsy.
  3. Patient is having an acute pancreatitis - True
    • History of alcohol use, sudden severe abdominal pain radiating to the back, and elevated amylase/lipase strongly support acute pancreatitis.
  4. Raised serum prolactin will always accompany the above condition - False
    • Serum prolactin is not associated with the diagnosis or pathogenesis of acute pancreatitis.
    • This option is incorrect and irrelevant in this context.

questions.text:
A patient presented with abdominal pain, and symptoms improved with steroid therapy. He was diagnosed with autoimmune pancreatitis. Which of the following findings (s) is/are true for autoimmune pancreatitis?
1. Ductocentric mixed inflammatory infiltrate
2. Increased IgG4-related plasma cells
3. Presence of venulitis
4. Clinical presentation can mimic pancreatic carcinoma.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Autoimmune pancreatitis is a pathogenically distinct form of chronic pancreatitis that responds well to steroids.
  1. Ductocentric mixed inflammatory infiltrate - True
    • Histology typically shows a dense inflammatory infiltrate around ducts containing lymphocytes, plasma cells, and sometimes eosinophils.
  2. Increased IgG4-related plasma cells - True
    • Autoimmune pancreatitis (Type 1) is part of IgG4-related systemic disease, marked by increased IgG4-secreting plasma cells in tissue.
  3. Presence of venulitis - True
    • A classic feature is obliterative phlebitis, also called venulitis, where inflammation and fibrosis obliterate veins within the pancreas.
  4. Clinical presentation can mimic pancreatic carcinoma - True
    • Patients often present with a pancreatic mass, jaundice, or weight loss, closely mimicking pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma, which makes histological confirmation crucial.

questions.text:
Which of the following is/are true for the pancreatic pseudocyst?
1. Lack of epithelial lining
2. Contains necrotic and haemorrhagic material
3. Requires surgical removal if more than 6.0 cm
4. It arises following a bout of chronic pancreatitis
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  1. Lack of epithelial lining - True:
    • Pseudocysts lack an epithelial lining. They are instead lined by granulation tissue and fibrosis, hence the term "pseudo."
  2. Contains necrotic and hemorrhagic material - True:
    • The contents often include degraded pancreatic enzymes, necrotic debris, and blood, resulting from tissue destruction during pancreatitis.
  3. Requires surgical removal if more than 6.0 cm - True:
    • Larger pseudocysts (typically >6 cm or persisting >6 weeks) are less likely to resolve spontaneously and more likely to cause complications; drainage or resection may be necessary.
  4. It arises following a bout of chronic pancreatitis - Incorrect
    • While pseudocysts may occur in chronic pancreatitis, they typically arise following acute pancreatitis, especially in cases related to alcohol abuse.

questions.text:
Which of the following are true for serous cystic neoplasm of the pancreas?
1. They usually occur in the tail of the pancreas
2. Present with abdominal pain
3. It is a benign neoplasm
4. Lined by columnar epithelium
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  1. They usually occur in the tail of the pancreas - True: Serous cystic neoplasms commonly arise in the tail or body of the pancreas.
  2. Present with abdominal pain - True: Although often asymptomatic, when symptoms are present, they are nonspecific, like abdominal pain or discomfort.
  3. It is a benign neoplasm - True: Serous cystadenomas are almost always benign, with no malignant potential. Surgical resection is curative when needed.
  4. Lined by columnar epithelium - False:
    • They are lined by glycogen-rich cuboidal epithelium, not columnar.
    • Columnar epithelium is a feature of mucinous cystic neoplasms, which are premalignant.

Comparative Table of Pancreatic Cystic Neoplasms:

questions.text:
Which of the following is/are TRUE for pancreatic carcinoma?
1. 60-80 years of age
2. Associated with cigarette smoking
3. It is the infiltrating ductal carcinoma of the pancreas
4. There is an activating mutation of CDKN2A
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Statements 1, 2, and 3 are true:

  1. Age 60-80 years: Pancreatic carcinoma primarily affects older adults, with peak incidence between 60 and 80 years.
  2. Association with cigarette smoking: Cigarette smoking is the most important environmental risk factor for pancreatic cancer, doubling the risk.
  3. It is the infiltrating ductal carcinoma of the pancreas: Over 90% of pancreatic cancers are infiltrating ductal adenocarcinomas, typically arising from pancreatic ducts.

Statement 4 is false:

  1. There is an activating mutation of CDKN2A:
    • CDKN2A (p16) is a tumour suppressor gene, and in pancreatic carcinoma, it is inactivated, not activated.
    • Mechanisms: point mutations, deletions, or promoter methylation in about 95% of cases.

questions.text:
Which of the following disorders is/are associated with the risk of pancreatic carcinoma?
1. Peutz-Jeghers syndrome
2. Hereditary pancreatitis
3. Familial atypical multiple-mole melanoma syndrome
4. Boerhaave syndrome
questions.solution:
Explanation:

1. Peutz-Jeghers Syndrome:

  • Gene: STK11 (LKB1) - tumour suppressor gene
  • Inheritance: Autosomal dominant
  • Features: Mucocutaneous pigmentation + hamartomatous polyps of the GI tract
  • Pancreatic cancer risk: High - 130× the general population
  • Mechanism: Loss of STK11 affects cellular polarity and growth regulation

2. Hereditary Pancreatitis:

  • Gene: PRSS1 (most common) or SPINK1
  • Inheritance: Autosomal dominant (PRSS1)
  • Features: Recurrent episodes of acute pancreatitis starting in childhood, progressing to chronic pancreatitis
  • Pancreatic cancer risk: Elevated - 50-80× the general population
  • Mechanism: Chronic inflammation causes repeated injury, leading to dysplasia and carcinoma

3. Familial Atypical Multiple Mole Melanoma (FAMMM) Syndrome:

  • Gene: CDKN2A (p16)
  • Inheritance: Autosomal dominant
  • Features: Numerous atypical nevi and increased risk of melanoma
  • Pancreatic cancer risk: Moderate - 20-35×
  • Mechanism: p16 inactivation promotes unregulated cell cycle progression

4. Boerhaave Syndrome:

  • Aetiology: Spontaneous oesophageal rupture due to sudden intraesophageal pressure rise (e.g., forceful vomiting)
  • Not associated with pancreatic malignancy
  • Inherited predisposition to pancreatic cancer:

questions.text:
Which of the following is/are the characteristic(s) of pancreatic carcinoma?
1. High invasiveness
2. Trousseau sign
3. Desmoplastic response
4. Troisier sign
questions.solution:
Explanation:

1. High invasiveness - Correct

  • Pancreatic carcinoma is highly aggressive and often invades nearby structures (e.g., vessels, duodenum) early in its course, contributing to its poor prognosis.
  • By the time of diagnosis, most tumours are unresectable due to local invasion or metastasis.

2. Trousseau sign - Correct

  • A paraneoplastic phenomenon, seen in ~10% of cases.
  • Characterised by migratory thrombophlebitis (recurrent blood clots in different veins), caused by procoagulants and platelet-activating factors released by the tumour.

3. Desmoplastic response - Correct

  • Pancreatic cancers, especially ductal adenocarcinomas, typically elicit a dense fibrotic (desmoplastic) stroma, making the tumour firm and infiltrative.
  • This response also impedes drug delivery, contributing to chemoresistance.

4. Troisier sign - Incorrect

  • Refers to a hard, enlarged left supraclavicular lymph node (Virchow's node).
  • Seen in gastric, lung, or other abdominal cancers with metastasis.
  • Not a defining feature of pancreatic cancer.

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reason are true, and the Reason is the correct explanation of the Assertion
Both Assertion and Reason are true, but the Reason is not the correct explanation of the Assertion
The assertion is true, but the Reason is false
The assertion is false, but the Reason is true

questions.text:
Assertion (A): Persons with pancreatic divisum and other genetic abnormalities are prone to develop chronic pancreatitis.
Reason (R): In pancreatic divisum, the bulk of the pancreas drains into the duodenum through the minor papilla.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Pancreas divisum is a congenital anomaly due to the failure of fusion of the dorsal and ventral pancreatic ducts.
  • As a result, the majority of the pancreas, derived from the dorsal primordium, drains via the minor papilla, which has a smaller caliber.
  • This anatomical setup may cause inadequate drainage of pancreatic secretions, especially under stress or in combination with genetic mutations (e.g., PRSS1, SPINK1).
  • These changes can increase intraductal pressure and lead to recurrent or chronic pancreatitis.
  • Therefore, both the Assertion and the Reason are true, and the Reason provides a valid causal explanation for the Assertion.

questions.text: A 19-year-old female college student presents to the campus medical clinic with complaints of fatigue that developed within the last few days. She also has a sore throat. She uses alcohol only occasionally. She does not use intravenous drugs or abuse prescription medication. Her past medical history is non-contributory. Her temperature is 99.9°F, pulse is 93 bpm, respiratory rate is 17 breaths per minute, and blood pressure is 100/75 mm Hg. A physical examination is non-contributory except for a palpable spleen and posterior cervical lymphadenopathy. Of the following, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient presents with classic features of infectious mononucleosis: fatigue, sore throat, posterior cervical lymphadenopathy, and splenomegaly, which are hallmarks of Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection.
  • This condition is most common in adolescents and young adults.

Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV) & Infectious Mononucleosis (IM)

Etiology & Transmission

  • EBV causes infectious mononucleosis, a benign, self-limited lymphoproliferative disorder.
  • Transmitted via saliva (e.g., kissing), hence nicknamed the 'kissing disease.'
  • Virus infects the oropharyngeal epithelium, then spreads to B cells in lymphoid tissue.

Pathogenesis

  • EBV infects B cells by binding to the CD21 receptor.
  • Infected B cells proliferate and express EBV-determined nuclear antigens (EBNAs).
  • A strong cytotoxic CD8+ T-cell response controls the infection, resulting in atypical lymphocytosis (Downey cells).
  • EBV remains latent in B cells for life.

Clinical Features

  • Common in adolescents and young adults.
  • Presents with fatigue, sore throat, fever, posterior cervical lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly
  • Splenomegaly may lead to splenic rupture after minor trauma.

Laboratory Findings

  • Atypical lymphocytes (CD8+ T cells) on peripheral smear.
  • Positive Monospot (heterophile antibody) test.
  • Elevated transaminases due to liver involvement.

Complications

  • Splenic rupture
  • Hepatitis
  • Association with EBV-related malignancies in immunosuppressed (e.g., Burkitt lymphoma, Hodgkin lymphoma, nasopharyngeal carcinoma, post-transplant lymphoproliferative disorder).

Explanation of other options:

Acute Lymphocytic Leukaemia (ALL) (Option A): Presents with pancytopenia, fatigue, bleeding, and bone pain. Lymphadenopathy and splenomegaly may be seen but are usually accompanied by severe cytopenias and blasts in the peripheral smear.

Follicular Lymphoma (Option B): A chronic B-cell lymphoma affecting older adults; presents with painless generalised lymphadenopathy and waxing and waning symptoms. It does not cause acute sore throat or splenomegaly with fever in young patients.

Subacute Bacterial Endocarditis (Option C): Occurs in patients with underlying valvular abnormalities or IV drug use. Presents with fever, new murmur, splenomegaly, and systemic embolic signs, but not with prominent cervical lymphadenopathy or sore throat.

questions.text: A 21-year-old female college student develops fatigue and a low-grade fever after a visit by her boyfriend, who goes to a different college in another state. During a massage given to her by a friend, her friend notes small swellings on the back of her neck. The next day, she goes horseback riding with her friends and falls from a horse onto a large pile of hay. Several minutes after the fall, she becomes unresponsive and ultimately dies. At autopsy, of the following, which is most likely to be identified by the forensic pathologist?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient presented with fever, fatigue, and posterior cervical lymphadenopathy, classic features of infectious mononucleosis, typically caused by Epstein-Barr virus (EBV).
  • One of the complications of infectious mononucleosis is splenomegaly, which can render the spleen fragile and prone to rupture, even after minor trauma.
  • In this case, the fall from the horse was likely sufficient to cause splenic rupture, leading to sudden hypotension, shock, and death.

Explanation of other options:

Ruptured coronary artery aneurysm (Option A): Rare in young individuals without underlying connective tissue disorders or Kawasaki disease. No history or findings support this.

Lacerated kidney (Option B): Possible with blunt trauma, but typically not immediately fatal unless bilateral or involving a major renal vessel, which is less likely here.

Lacerated aorta (Option C): Usually associated with high-impact trauma (e.g., car accidents) rather than a fall onto hay. Not the most likely cause here.

choices.text: It is more common in smokers
K-RAS mutation, p53 mutations and/or accumulation, and inactivation of tumor suppressor genes SMAD4/ DPC4 and p16 are common in this lesion.
It commonly occurs in the head of the pancreas

questions.text: A 64-year-old man presented with a weight loss of 25 pounds, lower back pain, and jaundice. A CT scan revealed an ill-defined mass in the head of the pancreas. Which of the following statements is true about this lesion?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The presentation (jaundice, back pain, weight loss) with a mass in the head of the pancreas is classic for pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma, the most common form of pancreatic cancer.

All options listed are correct:

  • Smoking is a well-established risk factor.
  • Genetic alterations frequently found include:
    • KRAS mutation (~90%)
    • p16/CDKN2A inactivation (~95%)
    • p53 mutation (~75%)
    • SMAD4/DPC4 inactivation (~55%)
  • Anatomic location: ~60% arise in the head of the pancreas.

Pancreatic Ductal Adenocarcinoma (PDAC):

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient who is a chronic alcoholic and has had uncontrolled diabetes for 5 years presented with a sudden onset of abdominal pain and vomiting. Pain is intense and referred to the back. The patient was sent for an ultrasound, which revealed a diagnosis of acute pancreatitis, and conservative management was done. If a biopsy were taken at this stage, what would be the histopathological findings you would observe?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The clinical picture is sudden, severe epigastric pain radiating to the back with vomiting in a patient with major risk factors (alcohol, metabolic stress from diabetes) → classic for acute pancreatitis, not chronic disease.
  • At the acute stage, histology ranges from interstitial oedema + fat necrosis to widespread parenchymal destruction. In severe cases, acini, ducts, and even islets undergo necrosis → acute necrotising pancreatitis; vascular injury can add hemorrhagic change.
  • Thus, if biopsied now, the dominant finding would be necrosis (± haemorrhage, fat saponification) rather than long-standing fibrotic remodelling.

Histopathology of Acute Pancreatitis

  • Key Morphologic Changes:
    • Microvascular leak & oedema
    • Fat necrosis (due to lipase → saponification → chalky white deposits)
    • Acute inflammation
    • Autodigestion of pancreatic parenchyma
    • Blood vessel destruction → interstitial haemorrhage
  • Forms:
    • Mild (Interstitial): Mild inflammation, interstitial oedema, focal fat necrosis.
    • Necrotising: Necrosis of acini, ducts, and islets.
    • Hemorrhagic: Extensive necrosis + intraparenchymal haemorrhage (red-black areas with chalky fat necrosis).
  • Spread: Fat necrosis may extend to the omentum, mesentery, and subcutaneous tissue.

Explanation of other options:

Parenchymal fibrosis (Option A): Hallmark of chronic pancreatitis; gland becomes hard and shrunken.

Acinar atrophy and dropout (Option B): Progressive loss of exocrine tissue with relative islet sparing; islets may appear 'trapped' in scar.

Variable ductal dilation (Option C): Irregular ducts; in alcoholic chronic pancreatitis, may contain protein plugs and calcifications; ductal epithelium may be atrophic or metaplastic.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented with weight loss of 15 kg. He also complains of lower back pain and jaundice. A CT scan revealed an ill-defined mass in the head of the pancreas. Proper excision and anastomosis operation by performed and sent for histopathological examination, the image of which is shown below. Which of the following genes is most commonly involved in such a tumor?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The case describes a pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma, the most common type of pancreatic cancer.
  • The image and history (weight loss, jaundice, ill-defined mass in the head of the pancreas) support this diagnosis.
  • KRAS mutation (on chromosome 12p) is the most frequently altered oncogene in pancreatic carcinoma.
  • Activating point mutations in KRAS are seen in >90% of cases, often at codon 12.
  • It plays a central role in early tumorigenesis and progression by activating MAPK and PI3K-AKT pathways.

Pancreatic Cancer Key Genetic Alterations:

Explanation of other options:

PTEN (Option B): Tumour suppressor gene involved in PI3K/AKT pathway regulation. Common in other malignancies (e.g., endometrial, glioblastoma), but not a major player in pancreatic carcinoma.

P53 (Option C): Mutated in about 75% of pancreatic cancers. Important, but not as frequent as KRAS.

RET (Option D): Proto-oncogene associated with medullary thyroid carcinoma and MEN 2 syndromes. Not involved in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female has had gallstones for 5 years. For the past 2 weeks, she has been experiencing intermittent abdominal pain. She now presents to the emergency department with acute severe pain in the right upper quadrant, associated with mild fever, nausea, vomiting, and tachycardia. She undergoes a laparoscopic cholecystectomy, and the specimen is sent for histopathological examination. What histological findings are expected to be seen?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient has a long-standing history of gallstones with intermittent abdominal pain that has recently worsened, along with fever, nausea, vomiting, and right upper quadrant tenderness, features suggestive of chronic cholecystitis with acute exacerbation.
  • Chronic cholecystitis is most commonly associated with long-standing gallstones and is the most frequent indication for cholecystectomy.
  • It results from recurrent or persistent inflammation of the gallbladder.

Histological Findings in Chronic Cholecystitis:

Gross Morphology:

  • The serosa is smooth and glistening, but in chronic cases may be dulled by subserosal fibrosis.
  • The gallbladder wall becomes thickened and may appear opaque gray-white.
  • Rokitansky-Aschoff sinuses (outpouchings of mucosa into the muscularis) may be prominent.
  • In long-standing cases, there may be calcification of the wall (porcelain gallbladder).

Microscopic Morphology:

  • Mild to moderate chronic lymphocytic infiltration is typically present in the mucosa and submucosa. (Option B)
  • Subserosal fibrosis is common and contributes to mural thickening. (Option C)
  • Hypertrophy of the muscular layer may also be seen. (Option A)
  • Rokitansky-Aschoff sinuses are lined by epithelium and may extend into or through the muscular layer.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with a dull aching pain in the epigastric region, associated with nausea and vomiting for 1 year. Total bilirubin is 4.4 mg/dL, and alkaline phosphatase is also raised. A USG examination reveals thickening of the gall bladder wall. After cholecystectomy, the specimen was sent for histopathological examination, the image of which is attached below. Based on the above findings, what is your probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Chronic dull epigastric pain, raised bilirubin and ALP, and wall thickening on USG suggest biliary obstruction.
  • Histopathology image (attached) reveals infiltrative glandular structures with cellular atypia: features consistent with adenocarcinoma.

Histopathological Features of Gallbladder Carcinoma:

Microscopy:

  • Most commonly adenocarcinoma
  • Infiltrative glands lined by malignant epithelial cells
  • Embedded in dense desmoplastic stroma
  • In some cases, cytologic atypia is minimal - diagnosis hinges on perineural and vascular invasion

Gross Morphology:

  • Typically affects the fundus
  • Maybe:
    • Exophytic mass protruding into the lumen
    • Or diffusely infiltrative, causing wall thickening (mimicking chronic cholecystitis)

Explanation of other options:

Chronic cholecystitis (Option A): Shows subserosal fibrosis, lymphocytic infiltration, Rokitansky-Aschoff sinuses - no invasive glands

Gallbladder polyp (Option B): Benign mucosal projection; lacks stromal invasion or atypia

Porcelain gallbladder (Option D): Refers to dystrophic calcification of the gallbladder wall, often associated with chronic cholecystitis, but not a malignant lesion itself (though it increases the risk of carcinoma)

questions.text: A 44-year-old patient presents with jaundice. He gives a history of a needle-prick injury 2 years ago. A liver biopsy is performed, and the histological image is shown below. Based on the histological features, what is the most likely type of hepatitis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The liver biopsy in this patient shows ground-glass hepatocytes, which are hepatocytes with a homogenous, finely granular, pink cytoplasm on H&E staining. This is characteristic of chronic Hepatitis B infection and is due to the accumulation of hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) within the cytoplasm.
  • Given the history of a needle-prick injury (parenteral exposure) and the biopsy findings, Hepatitis B is the most likely diagnosis.

Explanation of Other Options:

Hepatitis C Virus-Induced Hepatitis (Option B): Hepatitis C typically shows lymphoid aggregates in portal tracts and steatosis (fatty change) in hepatocytes, not ground-glass cells. It is an RNA virus and a leading cause of chronic liver disease, but the histology differs from HBV.

Hepatitis A Virus-Induced Hepatitis (Option C): HAV causes acute, self-limiting hepatitis. Histologically, you'd see spotty necrosis, apoptotic (acidophilic) bodies, and a mononuclear infiltrate - but not ground-glass hepatocytes.

Hepatitis E Virus-Induced Hepatitis (Option D): Similar to HAV, HEV also causes acute hepatitis, often in pregnant women in developing countries. Histology resembles HAV, without specific features like ground-glass cells.

questions.text: Liver biopsy from a patient shows dark brownish-black deposits in hepatocytes, canaliculi, Kupffer cells, and ductules. Polarised microscopy of the same shows maltese cross picture of red birefringence in the larger deposits. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Erythropoietic protoporphyria (EPP) is characterized by deposition of protoporphyrin, a brownish-black pigment, in the liver, involving hepatocytes, canaliculi, Kupffer cells, and ductules.
  • Under polarized light, the deposits show a Maltese cross with red birefringence, a hallmark of EPP.
  • May progress to cholestasis, liver failure, or cirrhosis.

Explanation of Other Options:

Melanosis (Option A): Refers to abnormal melanin deposition; not relevant to liver pathology and does not show Maltese cross birefringence.

Dubin-Johnson syndrome (Option B): There is black liver discoloration grossly, due to coarse, granular pigment (polymerized epinephrine metabolites), mainly in centrolobular hepatocytes. Clinically associated with conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, but not with ductular deposits or Kupffer cell pigmentation.

Hepatitis B (Option D): Does not cause pigment deposition. Histology shows ground-glass hepatocytes (due to HBsAg accumulation), interface hepatitis, and lobular inflammation

questions.text: A 61-year-old man presents with leg swelling (grade 2 pitting oedema up to the knees), prominent jugular venous distention extending to the mandible, and elevated serum AST and ALT levels. The gross appearance of the liver is shown below. Based on these findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The gross "nutmeg liver" appearance and microscopic findings of red cell congestion and hepatocyte atrophy in centrilobular (zone 3) areas are classic for chronic passive congestion, typically due to right-sided heart failure.
  • In this setting, hepatic venous outflow is impaired, leading to congestion, hypoxia, and eventually centrilobular necrosis.
  • Portal areas remain relatively preserved, helping distinguish it from other hepatic pathologies

Gross Morphology (Nutmeg Liver):

  • Liver appears enlarged, tense, and cyanotic
  • Cut surface shows a variegated, mottled red and tan appearance
    • Red areas: Congested centrilobular zones with haemorrhage
    • Tan areas: Relatively preserved periportal parenchyma
  • Appearance resembles a nutmeg seed → hence the name

Microscopy:

  • Centrilobular sinusoids are dilated and packed with RBCs
  • Centrilobular hepatocyte atrophy or necrosis
  • Periportal hepatocytes and portal tracts are preserved
  • In long-standing cases: Pericellular fibrosis in centrilobular areas → may lead to cardiac sclerosis

Explanation of other options:

Portal vein thrombosis (Option A): Causes prehepatic portal hypertension. Leads to splenomegaly, ascites, and formation of portal-systemic collaterals (e.g., oesophagal varices). Liver is typically normal in size and consistency; it does not show a mottled or congested appearance like in chronic venous congestion.

Cirrhosis (Option B): Represents chronic liver injury with fibrosis and regenerative nodule formation. Grossly, the liver appears shrunken, firm, and nodular (not congested or variegated). Microscopically shows bridging fibrosis and nodular regeneration, not centrilobular haemorrhage.

Fatty liver (hepatic steatosis) (Option C): Commonly associated with alcoholism, obesity, diabetes, and metabolic syndrome. Grossly, the liver is enlarged, yellow, and greasy in appearance. Microscopically, hepatocytes show intracytoplasmic fat vacuoles, not congestion or haemorrhage.

questions.text: The condition depicted in the image is associated with which of the following pathogenic mechanisms?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The image shows classic cholesterol concretions occupying the gallbladder lumen.
  • These develop due to multiple interrelated factors:
    • Hypomotility of the gall bladder leads to bile stasis, favouring retention of crystals.
    • Accelerated nucleation of cholesterol crystals results from bile supersaturation with cholesterol.
    • Hypersecretion of mucus provides a matrix that promotes crystal aggregation and growth.

questions.text: A patient presented with cirrhosis. Liver biopsy showed eosinophilic, rope-like cytoplasmic inclusions that were cytokeratin-positive. These structures are most likely composed of:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The image described corresponds to Mallory hyaline (Mallory-Denk bodies), which appear as eosinophilic, rope-like cytoplasmic inclusions in ballooned hepatocytes.
  • These are composed of intermediate filaments, particularly keratin 8 and keratin 18, that have undergone cytoskeletal damage, partial degradation, and ubiquitination.
  • They are commonly associated with alcoholic steatohepatitis, though also seen in NASH, Wilson disease, and chronic cholestatic liver diseases.

Explanation of other options:

Actin (Option A): Actin is part of the microfilament system and is not involved in the formation of Mallory-Denk bodies.

Microtubule (Option B): Microtubules are made of tubulin and function in intracellular transport, not in Mallory body composition.

Microfilaments (Option D): Microfilaments, composed of actin, are a separate cytoskeletal component not seen in Mallory-Denk inclusions.
